review_text:
b"Wow. Amazing story, and well told - kept me up late at night! Louie Zamperini truly went through hell and came back - and it's inspiring to read a story of such willpower and determination. It was also interesting to me to learn more about Japan and their role in the war. 
 One big takeaway was just how cheap human life is in war. I think there was some stat about how 5/6 of the US airmen that died did so from accidents - that is simply staggering. 
 I love WWII stories, but most of the ones I've seen and read have focused on Germany, so I really didn't know much about how Japan had treated their POW's. It was pretty eye opening to read the stats about how they pretty much massacred hundreds of thousands of POW's. And of couse, as the story details, they also did not follow Geneva Conventions and pretty much treated POW's as slaves. 
 One of my favorite points the author made is best illustrated by this quote about Dignity is as essential to human life as water, food, and oxygen. This is a fundamental truth of humanity that the author really drew out well - if you take a persons dignity away you take everything away. I loved all the stories of POW's being defiant; stealing food, supplies, playing jokes, etc. The little bits of defiance were enough to let them take back their dignity, and I think thats what makes them so compelling; because while we haven't all been POW's, we can relate to that basic need."
description:

review_text: b'If this book had been fiction, I wouldn\'t have liked it much. No one could make up a story like this and have it be believable. But because it\'s a biography of a real person (who is STILL alive in 2014!) this story captivated and inspired me. About three-quarters of the way through I had decided on giving it a solid four stars, probably bumping it up to four and a half in the review. But those last few chapters elevated this book to five stars for me. \n I kept reading in disbelief and horror and sadness and compassion and triumph. This book is superbly written and is everything nonfiction should be: engaging, thought-provoking, painstakingly detailed, and inspiring. The whole time I was reading I kept thinking, "WOW. Louis really is this person, and he\'s real. People really can be this good." I also loved the detail poured into peripheral characters like Phil, Louise, Sylvia, Pete, Cynthia, and even the Bird. \n Unbroken is a must-read, even if nonfiction isn\'t usually your thing. I read a library copy of this book and fully intend to buy my own copy to populate my shelves. Yes, this book was educational and offered me valuable perspective on war, but more importantly this book taught me that we are divinely designed to survive and heal and live.'

review_text: b'This is a wonderfully researched and compelling story of Louie Zamperini and his amazing/horrific/inspirational journey from his days as a wild childhood terror to becoming an Olympic star, from a dedicated World War II soldier to a 47-day castaway survivor, followed by his experiences as a war prisoner and finally a veteran who battles inner demons just as threatening as his war-time enemies. \n Simply put, Unbroken is a must-read.'

review_text:
b'The Pacific theater of World War II is often overlooked. It is an interesting phenomena, and I've often wondered, why? A function of the incredible geographic sprawl? Less concern, connection, or cultural empathy by Americans for Asia as opposed to Europe? Is it the cost of alliance with Japan? Embarrassment over the decision to unleash atomic weapons? 
 Whatever the reason, Laura Hillenbrand noticed it as well and responded with an epic biography from which she explores the big picture of the war in the Pacific. While the core of the book is Zamperini's story, Hillenbrand complements his narrative with a mountain of interviews mined from people who knew Zamperini or shared some part of his experience, examination of both published and unpublished work passed down through families, and voluminous research of public records. Zamperini's biography flows from childhood, through high school athletics, NCAA track competition, the 1936 Berlin Olympics, the army air corps, crashing, floating with the Pacific currents, capture by Japan, imprisonment, the end of the war, release, PTSD, and a spiritual awakening that beckons him to forgiveness and peace! 
 The writing was good, and the overall story had the 'feel' of authenticity when compared with other accounts from WWII. The reality is, everyone who survived had a story, and a nagging anxiety regarding why they made it and others didn't. Maybe they didn't have as long a story as Zamperini, or weren't the story teller he was - there is no doubt in my mind that the man has the gift of verbal modulation - but there is a story. Accounts of war and tremendous suffering, such as took place in the POW or concentration camps, often sound incredible to those who have not known the anguish humanity is capable of enduring, and those who have survived them are generally reluctant to discuss them with innocents resistant to their alarm. The last 20% of the book (I read on ebook so my page assessment may be off) was citations. I thought complaints about sourcing and reliability are unfounded, and I'm not willing to hold Zamperini's narrative gifts against him. 
 The experience of the army air corps in the Pacific was sobering. The deep trauma of Japanese POWs was articulated to a level I had not known. Furthermore, the consequences of the US-Japanese alliance - the sacrifice of justice for POWs was disturbing. Yet who can argue with the results that were won by these men? A strong, enduring alliance has been forged between the two countries. Reading this book, though, helped me to understand the enduring animosity toward Japan by some in the Greatest Generation. 
 The trauma of the war didn't end with the agreement between powers, at least not for the soldiers. No one should dismiss this as a "Jesus book." While it is true that Christianity played a significant role in turning Zamperini from the destructive road down which war trauma was leading him and restored to him his vivacious, garrulous personality, it is clear that Hillenbrand herself is not a believer. I found her 'outside the fold' coverage of Billy Graham to be balanced, fair and fascinating. 
 In recent years, it has become fashionable to question the USA's use of the atomic bomb. No one doubts it was a sobering decision. The testimony of the POWs documented here seem to strongly support President Truman's difficult decision. In case of invasion, the POWs were living under a kill order, with thousands of men being moved and/ or prepared for execution. These orders had been carried out in case of invasion earlier in the war. The Japanese people, indoctrinated with a strong cultural resistance to surrender, were preparing to defend their island to the last men (elderly), women and children. The losses in the war were already tremendous and over a hundred thousand POWs were crying out for liberation. The loss of Japanese life from the bombs was horrific, but the equation that states it may have saved hundreds of thousands, if not millions of Allied, particularly US lives, seems reasonable. 
 Finally, I was captivated by the author herself as she shared within the notes of the book her own monumental struggle to write while wrestling with debilitating chronic illness. Her personal story was an encouragement to me, her writing an education. I have included some links below if you would like to know more of her. 
 After reading about the war from a soldier's perspective, I had to finally tackle David McCoullough's biography of Truman to seek insight into the man that liberated the Japanese POWs. 
 Truman, McCoullough, 1992 
 https://www.goodreads.com/review/edit... 
 More on the Pacific theater of World War II, particularly the Doolittle Raid, and Japan after the war: 
 Jacob DeShazer, Benge & Benge, 2009 
 https://www.goodreads.com/review/show... 
 Another woman who completed a similar quest to document a subject's memoirs within the historical context of their time, but on a completely different topic see: 
 The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, Skloot, 2010 
 https://www.goodreads.com/review/show... 
 LAURA HILLENBRAND 
 An article describing the Author's descent into illness.... 
 A Sudden Illness, Hillenbrand, 2003 
 http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/200... 
 Leaving Frailty Behind: An interview with Laura Hillenbrand, Stanford Medical Review, Costello, 2016 
 http://stanmed.stanford.edu/2016summe...'

review_text:
b"Not a lot to say about this one that hasn't been said better by a lot of other folks. So popular that it has taken ages for me to get a copy from the local library. But well worth the wait. 
 By the author of Seabiscuit, another cracking good tale. Seabiscuit was made into a critically acclaimed movie. Unbroken has also been filmed but I wanted to wait until I read the book to see the movie. Looking forward soon to having that pleasure. 
 This book, like Seabiscuit, is exhaustively researched and extremely well written. The old cliche applies: reads like a novel. 
 In brief it tells the incredible true story of an Olympic athlete and World War II airman who endured catastrophes that I could never even begin to imagine. A triumph of the human spirit over all the odds. If you are looking for something inspirational or simply a really good story I would suggest given Unbroken a look."

review_text:
b'Powerful. Riveting. Beautiful. Probably the best book I have read this year. 
 "Unbroken" was our book club choice for the month, and I picked it up somewhat reluctantly. It seemed awfully big and I worried it would be too slow and too depressing. How glad I am that it was chosen! I am going to buy a permanent copy to keep and maybe one for my Dad for Christmas. 
 The book follows the life of Louis Zamperini, a troubled youth turned Olympic runner. He is preparing for the next Olympic games when Pearl Harbor arrives and the country is thrown into war. Louie becomes a reluctant bombardier on a B-24 Liberator. It follows his time as an active soldier, his unfortunate crash, dealing with sharks for weeks on end and no food or water, a horrifying internment in a Japanese POW camp, and his journey home seeking healing and redemption. I am leaving out spoiler after spoiler, giving as little information as possible so as not to ruin anything. But what a life! 
 And what a writer Laura Hillenbrand is. Here is a woman who struggles with severe chronic fatigue and yet was able to slowly produce this incredible work. I have read much non-fiction, I have read WW2 books, Holocaust books, etc etc, but never have I felt so sucked into someone's life. I felt what Louie felt. As his plane is going down over the Pacific and he and his crewmates stare at each other in horror, I truly felt that horror. I caught myself breathing fast with my heart banging against my chest. Again and again I felt like I was there, living it with them. I will also say that Hillenbrand strikes such an important balance--she lays out the gravity of the situation without tipping into graphic unnecessary shock value. There were many times I could hardly stop turning the pages. Amazing that it is a true story. 
 The ending of the book deals so much with forgiveness and redemption. Louis has an understandably difficult time rejoining society at the close of the war. I could not help but compare my own Grandfather, who saw such terrible things in the Pacific theater and turned to alcohol to try to deal with the pain once he came home. 
 I closed the book inspired, hopeful, and touched by his life and choices. I encourage anyone to read this important story.'

review_text:
b"For whatever reason, I put off reading this book for a looooong time. I don't generally reach for non-fiction, and I had an idea that this might read a little slow, or be a little preachy, or somehow not hold my interest. 
 Boy, was I wrong. 
 Laura Hillenbrand, who was amazing with Seabiscuit, too, could probably write the story of just about anything and it would be unputdownable. But here she has great subject matter in Olympic runner/WWII POW Louis Zamparini. 
 The story is absolutely fantastic. Painful to read at times, but eye-opening and completely redemptive. 
 On a side note: My grandpa, stationed at Canton Island, was one of the GIs throwing grenades into the mouths of sharks surrounding the atoll. Reading about the dangerous landings and refuelings at Canton, I gained a deeper understanding and respect for his wartime experiences."

review_text: b'I love track and field and I love American history, so I had high expectations for this book. I was not disappointed. Taking the good with the bad, Hillenbrand tells of a wild kid who found a purpose in running. Louis Zamperini made the Olympic team and had the most potential of any runner of his time. His running career was interrupted by WWII. He became a POW in Japan and suffered horrible cruelty and deprivation. He survives, but comes home to struggle with the trauma of what he had survived. Well written, interesting and hard to put down.'

review_text: b'Surprisingly, I sped through this nonfiction book at a pace that equaled my reading of fiction. It was written in a way that kept my interest throughout, because even though it was about war and the inherent atrocities therein, it was a story about a very interesting life. After reading about the attempts to normalize relations with Japan after the war, I now understand why I had several Japanese pen pals when I was in elementary school. Shuichi Takeda is the only name I can remember. I thoroughly enjoyed this book, and will read Seabiscuit because of it.'

review_text: b"I found myself speed-reading this instead of taking a leisurely pace. I enjoyed the first section of the book which detailed his time as a child leading up to the 1936 Olympics. I found the section detailing his army training to be belabored. It seemed like that part could have been shortened a bit. While he was lost at sea, I was incredulous about how he dealt with the sharks. It just seemed exaggerated. His time as a POW was a bit painful to read simply because of content, but that is to be expected. His time after the war leading up to his salvation was, again, a bit belabored. I realize that I am simply not a fan of biographies. Every time I have attempted one, I end up not liking it too much. Conversely, I do like memoirs. I feel like it's almost disrespectful to dislike this book, but I do. I think that for a biography, it is very well-done. For that alone, it is a 5. For my personal tastes, a 2."

review_text: b'I am simply one of the countless readers who feel all the richer for having read this book. "Unbroken" is a compelling, extraordinary account of endurance, courage, and tenacity that transcends the realms of imagination. Whether you are a fan of non-fiction and survival stories or not, this book is a must-read. Besides the dire, unspeakable, conditions that Louie Zamperini and thousand others had to suffer, it is the men\'s sheer will to survive and their resourcefulness in the face of starvation, torture and certain death that I found absolutely staggering. How in the world does the human spirit, time and again on the verge of hopelessness and doom, and with no physical strength to back it, rally to defy submission and defeat? \n By virtue of Laura Hillenbrand\'s sleight of hand, one would think this book has virtually written itself. The flow of the story masks the colossal task the author had tackled to sift through and transcribe scores of interviews, documents and personal accounts. She deserves every accolade for her achievement and more. She has brought to light the sheer resilience of one man that speaks volumes for others.'

review_text: b"EXCELLENT!!! This book starts out with the interesting youth of Louie. I was able to put the book down at this point, not because it was dull, but because they were like short stories with natural breaking points. Once I hit his flying in the Pacific, I was glued to the pages. I didn't put it down until I was done. I thought it was almost 9 at night, but it was almost 10 and I still had to put my 5 kiddos to bed!! My voice is a little hoarse from yelling at them when they interrupted me with their petty fighting. I actually was a pretty bad mom and will have to make up for it today :-) I can do that since finished the book at 1:30 this morning. I also realy liked how Hillenbrand highlighted other heros in the book. Even though they weren't the main character, she distinguished their valor. Highly recommend!!"

review_text: b"A well-written nonfiction story of one man's survival against all odds, this novel is illustrative of the horrific crimes men can commit against other men--and of the redemptive nature of good character in the face of adversity. Hard to put down, this book made me want to know more about both the Pacific theater in World War II and its protagonist, Louis Zamperini (I spent an afternoon reading stuff on the Internet because of it). Wanting more is always a good sign when reading nonfiction. On a par with Hillenbrand's earlier effort, Seabiscuit."

review_text: b"Mr. Zamperini's remarkable story could have not been in better hands than those of Laura Hillenbrand. How he or any of the soldiers who were held by the Japanese survived, is a miracle. There are only a rare few that could have endured what these soldiers endured. Zamperini's never-give-up attitude, brought to mind Ellie Wiesel."

review_text: b'Some books are read while others are experienced. Unbroken is an "experience" book. It answered so many questions for me-formost my own father\'s prejudices and his own triumph over these prejudices. My seven year old father was playing football on a Sunday morning when he rushed home after hearing Pearl Harbor had been bombed. He grew up with the stories of Pacific WWII POWs. I never understood why he wouldn\'t buy a Japanese car--but now I do and now I appreciate that the day came when he made a conscientious choice to let that prejudice go. \n When I was seventeen years old, Mr. Kono, my Japanese host, called me into his dining room to present me with a scroll that read peace. He told me that he could not forgive and forget what the Americans did to his people but his daughter and me--we needed to forget. How wise and tender that moment has become to me. When I read this book, I felt a backlash towards Mr. Kono\'s resentment, but yet immediately thought of Japanese Americans who were mistreated by Americans--and then an awakening that this is not a cultural/country problem, but a humanity problem. \n Zamperini only overcame his hate by the power of Jesus Christ. What a humbling lesson. What a great book.'

review_text: b'Well, I can finally grow my fingernails out again! I would seriously sit and CHEW my nails down to nothing while reading this book, so yeah, I would call it a "nail biter". \'Unbroken\' is the perfect title for this book, and SO many times I wondered how he couldn\'t yet be broken. It was one thing after another. The crash, the time spent on the raft, the capture, the camps, the mistreatment, the after effects, the PSTD...how can one person endure so much? How can the human soul be so resilient? How can one come back from a total loss of dignity? This is a must read. Certain parts left me stunned. Gasping out loud. Disgusted. Frightened. Sad....so many emotions in one book.'

review_text: b'This book was fantastic. Finally there is a well written book about US involvement in WWII in the Pacific! Considering that the attack on Pearl Harbor was the reason the US entered the war, it has always bothered me that the discourse on WWII in the US educational system essentially ignores the war outside of Europe. Everyone who wants to learn more about the Pacific side of the war and its atrocities through the story of some of the men who lived it should read this book. I also loved the lengthy introduction to Louie that captured who he was as a person. This book was horrific and heartbreaking and yet offered so much in terms of healing and redemption. It was thoroughly human, and I loved that about it. To all those who sacrificed so much in the conflict, both those who survived and those who did not, I salute you.'

review_text: b"Wow. What a powerful story. For me, it was a glimpse into a part of World War II history that I don't know much about. I especially enjoyed learning about the Japanese cultural influences on the war and what it was like to endure a POW encampment. This story instilled in me an even deeper respect and appreciation for our nation's heroes, the ones who survived and the ones who made the ultimate sacrifice."

review_text: b"Wow. That was one of the most awful books I have ever been forced to read. I learned way more about WWII planes then I ever cared to know...and had way too much insight into POW camps. Really...way, way too much. They could have summed all of that up in like five pages, but instead we had to suffer through 150 pages of that. I understand that these men went through hell for our freedom and I think that's wonderful. But they went through it so that we didn't have to...even vicariously through the written word. I liked the end how he turned his life around and made a difference in the world, that was great. I liked the lost at sea bit and the training for the Olympics was interesting as well. But really parts II and IV kind of ruined the whole book for me."

review_text: b"Unbroken was such a fantastic story, concerning the life of Louis Zamperini. Note that I said the story was fantastic-this book could have easily rated a five, but I have to be bluntly honest...if Laura Hillenbrand's two books (at least the two I know about) hadn't contained such absolutely engaging topics, I would have to rate them 2's at best. I loved the details of Louis' life, but Hillenbrand's writing was dry, boring, and mundane. Even as enthralled as I was with Louis and his life, I found myself struggling to read more than 25 pages at a time, which is just plain sad. \n So, my recommendation-read the book to get the story behind the man, but don't expect to be bedazzled by the writing."

review_text:
b'An indomitable spirit 
 It was fortunate that Louis Zamperini learned survival and persistence against all odds from a very early age. It was largely responsible for his survival through hardships of being adrift in the Pacific Ocean on a rapidly dwindling raft, fighting starvation, avoiding sharks, capture by the Japanese and captivity, brutality and more starvation in a POW camp for over two years until Allied liberation after the surrender of Japan in 1945. 
 Raised by Italian immigrants in the small coastal town of Torrance, California, Louie ran everywhere, got into fights as well as small time burglaries and pranks. His older brother Pete saw his potential and encouraged him to pursue track throughout high school and consider running professionally. Running was the saving grace of Louie's early life and it finally led him to compete in the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, where Jesse Owens emerged triumphant in sight of the enraged Hitler. Speaking of Hitler, he was actually impressed by the young white athlete. Hitler reached out his hand from his stand above. "You're the boy with the fast finish," he said to Louie, who reached up and, too low to shake the Fuhrer's hand, touched his fingers. 
 When World War II arrived Louie, as well as millions of other young men, enlisted. He became a bombardier in the Army Air Corps and flew with his good friend and pilot Allen 'Phil' Phillips. When their plane was shot down, only three survived--Louie, Phil and another crew member they called Mac. They clung to a small raft and held onto their meager provisions, which included a few pieces of chocolate. Louie and Phil wanted to ration the chocolate to last at least a few days but on the morning after the first night they saw that all the chocolate was gone. Mac had a guilty look on his face. Louie's and Phil's attitudes to the same circumstances differed from Mac and they were able to survive while he succumbed to despair. Mac began wasting away. Nevertheless, he redeemed himself to the point that, without his help, Louie would not have been able to fend away a huge shark. Mac became heroic just before he started dying. 
 Rescued by the wrong side, Louie and Phil were taken first to Kwajelein, known as 'execution island,' due to its reputation for murdering most of its POWs, then to Naoestsu, on the western coast of Japan. One of the commanding officers, Mutsuhiro Watanabe, nicknamed 'the Bird', had a reputation for sadism and brutality even among other Japanese officers, once he realized the notoriety of Louie's previous life, he made it a point of pride to single him out and break his will. Two things Louie would never allow himself to do: bow to 'the Bird' or avert his gaze from the Bird's eyes, even after doing so certainly resulted in additional beatings. 
 Hillenbrand explains the attitude of the Japanese soldiers: 
 'Few societies treasured dignity, and feared humiliation, as did the Japanese, for whom a loss of honor could merit suicide. This is likely one of the reasons why Japanese soldiers in World War II debased their prisoners with such zeal, seeking to take from them that which was most painful and destructive to lose. On Kwajalein, Louie and Phil learned a dark truth known to the doomed in Hitler's death camps, the slaves of the American South, and a hundred other generations of betrayed people. Dignity is as essential to human life as water, food, and oxygen. The stubborn retention of it, even in the face of extreme physical hardship, can hold a man's soul in his body long past the point at which the body should have surrendered it. The loss of it can carry a man off as surely as thirst, hunger, exposure, and asphyxiation, and with greater cruelty. In places like Kwajalein, degradation could be as lethal as a bullet.' 
 As word spread that the Allies were encroaching through enemy lines in the Pacific, the POWs were not encouraged. In addition to the daily beatings, starvation and subhuman conditions, they heard repeatedly that the Japanese would execute all of the prisoners before they would surrender. Finally, after word spread that two atom bombs had been dropped and the end was in sight, the POWs were liberated and free to leave the camp. All of the camp commanders fled. 
 Hillenbrand spends much of the last portion of the book chronicling Louie's post-war life, the post-traumatic stress that sabotaged any attempt at a prosperous life as Louie almost completely destroyed his marriage and neglected his wife and small children, sinking deeper into alcoholism. He suffered nightmares of the Bird torturing him and became obsessed with the idea of tracking him down and killing him. His wife's repeated suggestions to check out the young evangelist Billy Graham were largely rebuffed until he grudgingly attended one of Graham's revivals and eventually surrendered his hatred and finally stopped having nightmares of the Bird altogether. Hillenbrand describes the self-torment of vengefulness: 
 'The paradox of vengefulness is that it makes men dependent upon those who have harmed them, believing that their release from pain will come only when they make their tormenters suffer. In seeking the Bird's death to free himself, Louie had chained himself, once again, to his tyrant. During the war, the Bird had been unwilling to get go of Louie; after the war, Louie was unable to let go of the Bird.' 
 Hillenbrand also traces the journey through the years of the Bird, who became a fugitive, trying to lose himself in a false identity as more and more war criminals were hunted down, tried and convicted. As the post-war climate changed and the United States helped Japan rebuild its economy, Japan became an ally and the attitude toward war criminals became more merciful. Long thought to have been dead, the Bird finally came out of hiding and resumed his life under his true identity. 
 When Louie learned that the Bird was still alive, he decided he would attempt to track him down not to kill him but to forgive him. Although at one time open to meeting Louie again, the Bird finally refused to see him, softening his tone but still falling short of a complete, honest confession free of rationalization. 
 The book is sprinkled generously by quotes from Louie telling his story. Never does he come across as self-congratulatory and he never presents himself as anything extraordinary. He has an even-handed acceptance of his shortcomings. Hillenbrand also maintains a neutral tone, impartially recounting the experiences without letting a personal opinion slip through. She does spend a bit more time on the worrying parents, sisters and brother than I would have preferred. I know that it's necessary to paint the complete picture of what those at home experienced but there's nothing they experienced that thousands of other families of POWs did as well. It is what Louie did that is extraordinary, that makes him worthy of being the subject of a book about his life. However, that is a minor quibble. Louis Zamperini is a hero not only because he survived a devastating series of hardships but because he also managed to turn his life around before allowing the war to make him another post-war casualty.'

review_text: b'This book was AMAZING. Hillenbrand retold a slice of the Pacific theater with all of its horrors and victories through Louie Zamperini\'s POV. Loui\'s own personal story is quite incredible, and at times I couldn\'t believe what I was reading. Although I\'ve read a few books on WWII and even on the Pacific Theater, I had not read a book that unearthed all of the horrors of the Japanese. I couldnt shake off the kill-all policy in my mind: Japanese would obliterate the POW camp if there was prospect of an Allied liberation. Hillenbrand also tried to make sense of the Japanese belief of such brutal treatments. I cried when the nice Japanese soldiers helped the Allied POWs (the first Japs that picked up Phil and Louie, Kawamura, Kano). I cheered when the POWs still defied their captors by stealing ("University of Thievery alumni"), destroying trains and cargo, and passing along pieces of information (Bill Harris). When the stolen goods were traded as currency in their camp microcosm of an economy, I was irritated when the Scots POWs made hard bargains on their stolen sugar ((like really? Y\'all are all prisoners there together- why be so harsh)). But I was consoled to learn that they also donated a quarter of their commodities to the sick POWs. I was surprised that POWs still kept rankings - deferring to the highest ranking officer in the camp, regardless of nationality. And finally, I was devastated to learn how perilous being an airman then: a 40 mission requirement with almost a 70% chance to not return. \n This book was so beautifully written. Seemingly random events would be described when they didn\'t contribute to the overall plot, until I read they somehow contributed as a strong flashback later in the story. It was as if the reader was also experiencing the flashback along with Louie rather than reading Louie experiencing this memory. These chronological memories intertwined the beginning to the end of the story. \n Although I knew this was a nonfiction book, I was originally a little disconnected from the book, from the history. But it wasn\'t until I read about a young injured airman at sea, something Reading, willingly giving up his life jacket to his healthier comrade and then "sinking away". He was 21. Reading this as a 20 year old, I was suddenly shaken at the reality of young soldiers of WWII. With that in mind, it was different reading WWII stories than when I was younger and thinking 20 yr olds were much older adults.'
description:
In her long-awaited new book, Laura Hillenbrand writes with the same rich and vivid narrative voice she displayed in . Telling an unforgettable story of a man's journey into extremity, Unbroken is a testament to the resilience of the human mind, body, and spirit.On a May afternoon in 1943, an Army Air Forces bomber crashed into the Pacific Ocean and disappeared, leaving only a spray of debris and a slick of oil, gasoline, and blood. Then, on the ocean surface, a face appeared. It was that of a young lieutenant, the plane's bombardier, who was struggling to a life raft and pulling himself aboard. So began one of the most extraordinary odysseys of the Second World War.The lieutenant's name was Louis Zamperini. In boyhood, he'd been a cunning and incorrigible delinquent, breaking into houses, brawling, and fleeing his home to ride the rails. As a teenager, he had channeled his defiance into running, discovering a prodigious talent that had carried him to the Berlin Olympics and within sight of the four-minute mile. But when war had come, the athlete had become an airman, embarking on a journey that led to his doomed flight, a tiny raft, and a drift into the unknown.
Ahead of Zamperini lay thousands of miles of open ocean, leaping sharks, a foundering raft, thirst and starvation, enemy aircraft, and, beyond, a trial even greater. Driven to the limits of endurance, Zamperini would answer desperation with ingenuity; suffering with hope, resolve, and humor; brutality with rebellion. His fate, whether triumph or tragedy, would be suspended on the fraying wire of his will.
title: Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption

review_text:
b":o :o :o (that's me after closing the book and it pretty much says it all) 
 How much can a human being suffer? What's the breaking point? 
 This book is a portrait of the human capacity to endure all forms of brutality - inflicited by both humans and nature- just for the sake of survival! 
 Laura Hillenbrand took us on a trip through the olympics, on B-29s planes over the pacific, in prisoners camps...and finally showed us the true human nature. 
 The writer's style is that which dares you i leave the page, and the story line -being a true story- is so emotional and powerful. 
 A highly recommended books and one of the best books i hve read this summer[?]"

review_text: b"This book was amazing on many levels. Zamperini's story is captivating, and the author does a wonderful job of telling it. I was enthralled throughout the whole book, and I especially loved the ending. Being a Christian myself, I was overjoyed with the ending and found great encouragement from Christ's healing power in his life. What a testimony to the power of God to change man's heart and to heal the spirit within. Loved it!"

review_text:
b'Beforehand I did not know what this book was about. While reading I then realized it must be about an athlete who wants to win a medal at the Olympics, then I decided ,no this book must be about the second world war.....After reading more I knew it, Finally this is a book about people that try to survive on a raft in the pacific. Again something happened and now I know, this is about prisoners of war camps and camps like Ofuna. 
 Well I can inform you, it is about all the things I mentioned and I have only read 41 % so go figure!!! wow! 
 Update: 13 August 2013. 
 Finished this book yesterday morning. 
 Wow what a story! 
 Okay I might hurt some people's feelings when is say this and that is not my intention so bare with me. 
 I live in The Netherlands, mum is English but we spoke Dutch and I grew up here. 
 Now from very early on I remember there was much talk at school and on TV about the second world war. Later when I grew up I've watched many TV programs about the as we call it concentration camps and about all the Jewish people that were murdered there. 
 There was also a lot of information about people that hid Jewish people (I do not like the word Jews) like Anne Frank and people that helped them try to escape the Germans. 
 So when I started reading this book and learned more about what had happened in Japan, the first question that was formed was"Huh why did I not know this"? 
 Was it because I did not pay attention in school? Do not think so because as a child I was fascinated by death and horror. (blushes) 
 So I think this must mean there is not near as much interest and coverage about the death camps in japan although I do know a lot of Dutch men were captured and murdered there. 
 It scares and angers me that Japan has managed to get away with so many things and some are even still denying all that has happened. 
 It annoys me even more that the US government can make deals in names of in this instance, POW's and agree with japan that they are not entitled to blame Japan or get any compensation money for all they had to endure. 
 Who do they bloody think they are!!! 
 Okay calm down Marlene. 
 Back to the book. As I said in the beginning, had no clue what this was about which makes it even more fun. 
 This author is a wonderful writer. It felt like I was there, She kept me interested and wanting to know more. 
 The story about the shipwreck was so hard to read. I was so happy when they were saved. (I thought). How sad that that was just a tip of the iceberg. 
 This is a fantastic book. Even though you think you do not like non fiction I say give this a try.'

review_text: b'Unbroken follows the story of Louie Zamperini, an olympic track runner who joined the ranks of the Army Air Force during World War II. Hillenbrand clearly and expertly chronicles Zamperinis harrowing tale of survival after his airplane crashes in the middle of the Pacific as he drifts over thousands of miles of ocean in a life raft--hungry sharks dogging them at every opportunity--and at last washes up on the shores of a Pacific island only to fall into the hands of the Japanese. \n This book covers many often neglected details of the war, primarily the incredible dangers of being in the air force at that time (where your airplane was more likely to crash because of mechanical failure than damage from enemy fire) and the brutal life of a Japanese Prisoner of War. And Hillenbrand brings it all together in a well-written, well-ordered, and cohesive tale that reads more like a fiction novel than a biography.'

description:
In her long-awaited new book, Laura Hillenbrand writes with the same rich and vivid narrative voice she displayed in . Telling an unforgettable story of a man's journey into extremity, Unbroken is a testament to the resilience of the human mind, body, and spirit.On a May afternoon in 1943, an Army Air Forces bomber crashed into the Pacific Ocean and disappeared, leaving only a spray of debris and a slick of oil, gasoline, and blood. Then, on the ocean surface, a face appeared. It was that of a young lieutenant, the plane's bombardier, who was struggling to a life raft and pulling himself aboard. So began one of the most extraordinary odysseys of the Second World War.The lieutenant's name was Louis Zamperini. In boyhood, he'd been a cunning and incorrigible delinquent, breaking into houses, brawling, and fleeing his home to ride the rails. As a teenager, he had channeled his defiance into running, discovering a prodigious talent that had carried him to the Berlin Olympics and within sight of the four-minute mile. But when war had come, the athlete had become an airman, embarking on a journey that led to his doomed flight, a tiny raft, and a drift into the unknown.
Ahead of Zamperini lay thousands of miles of open ocean, leaping sharks, a foundering raft, thirst and starvation, enemy aircraft, and, beyond, a trial even greater. Driven to the limits of endurance, Zamperini would answer desperation with ingenuity; suffering with hope, resolve, and humor; brutality with rebellion. His fate, whether triumph or tragedy, would be suspended on the fraying wire of his will.
title: Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption
processed_text: a true story of redemption and forgiveness that will stretch your understanding of forgiveness

review_text: b"Wow, I thought this was a completely amazing book. It was so well-researched and detailed... incredible considering that most of the events took place over 60 years ago! It is horrible to think about the capacity for violence that some people have inside of them. Some of the things the guards did to their prisoners literally turned my stomach. I can't imagine surviving under those conditions. Louie's story is especially inspiring because after the war, he overcame his alcoholism and desire for revenge and went on to have a fulfilling life with his family. I enjoyed learning more about World War 2. I am far from a history buff so a lot of it was new for me!"

review_text:
b'The answer to the question, "How much abuse can one man take?" is - a lot. 
 Louis Zamperini has lived one of the most amazing stories in US history. A juvenile delinquent of the thieving/house-breaking variety, he was lucky enough to have a brother who opened him up to a shot at redemption through sports, in Louis' case running, and in short time Louis became a contender at Hitler's Berlin Olympiad, and one of the fastest men ion earth. When WWII broke out he became a bombardier in the Army Air Force. Shot down over the Pacific, he and a buddy broke the record for survival at sea - and suffered greatly in the manner of starvation, dehydration, and near madness. Picked up by the Japanese, he was interred in a prison camp ruled by a sadist who took a particular interest in torturing him, and I won't tell you more except to say Louis Zamperini survived those and further horrors to become a man whose story should be known. 
 Laura Hillenbrand, the author of Seabiscuit, tells Louis' story without histrionics, but with a compelling style. She certainly knows how to write about running, and her eye for detail also takes us into the' worlds of war, prison camps, and returning vets without unnecessary shock but with an honesty that makes Unbroken an emotional thriller. 
 There have been some interesting questions raised about the reliability of Louis' memory in that the details are so shocking. I suspect there are embellishments here and there, but I'd be hard pressed to say just where. The entire story is very well documented, so I'm willing to give the benefit of the doubt. 
 The one flaw, for me, was the abrupt ending of the main narrative and the jump to an epilogue. It seemed too abrupt - especially given the detail of the preceding chapters, but I was drawn quickly back into the flow.. 
 I've always thought redemption the subject of the greatest art, and though this isn't great art redemption elevates it way beyond the reportage it could have been. 
 A helluva read.'

review_text: b"Let me begin by saying I almost never read dramas or history or non-fiction works, usually they don't appeal to me in anyway. This book is the ultimate exception to that rule. The intensity and pace never slow throughout the giant book. The events of Louis Zamperini's life are utterly amazing and unforgettable. Laura Hillenbrand is an absolute genius on the page, giving the reader insight into Zamperini's life from a riotous youth to his years as an senior. Even the statistics peppered throughout the novel will put you awe. Absolutely stunning!"

review_text: b"I'm not a big nonfiction fan but this book captivated me. It was well written and well researched. \n The story itself was too unbelievable to be true. I found myself Googling Zamperini's life to check the facts and was surprised to find these stories were really true. I learned more about World War II and specifically the Pacific theater in this book than I did in my entire scholastic career."

review_text: b"I'm amazed by the resilience of both Louie Zamperini and the author of Unbroken, Laura Hillenbrand. The former endured the harshest physical treatment during his time as a POW and the latter has suffered in isolation due to chronic fatigue syndrome that has plague her for years. I'm inspired by both of their lives and have learned a great deal about the Japanese involvement in WWII."

review_text: b"What I found surprising, and what I was unaware of until after finishing Hillenbrand's book, is that Louis Zamperini actually wrote and published his own memoir titled Devil at my Heels (first in 1956, then again in 2003) which is available used from Amazon.com. How do the two titles differ? Your guess is as good as mine, though it does seem a bit odd to me that Hillenbrand would want to tackle the subject of Zamperini's life well after Zamperini himself had done so in his own words. \n READ MORE: \n http://www.opinionless.com/book-revie..."

review_text:
b"http://mariesbookgarden.blogspot.com/... 
 My sister and husband both read Unbroken for their respective book groups and loved it. I was looking forward to diving in, and it did not disappoint. 
 Unbroken is the true story of Louis Zamperini, destined to be the world's fastest miler. He spent his childhood getting into one scrape after another and seemed destined to be a failure until he discovered running. He participated in the 1936 Olympics (presided over by Hitler) but would be in his prime at the 1940 and 1944 Olympics. Sadly, the 1940 Games were cancelled, and he was otherwise occupied in 1944. 
 When World War II broke out, Zamperini enlisted in the Army Air Forces and was stationed in Hawaii. While flying in a plane over the Pacific to rescue another plane that had not returned from a mission, Zamperini and his crewmates crash-landed in the ocean. Amazingly, he and the two other survivors floated on a life raft for 47 days--drinking rain water, eating raw fish and birds they caught with their hands, and telling stories to keep themselves sanee--before drifting to one of the Marshall islands, where they were captured by the Japanese. 
 This is nonfiction at its best: I learned about running, life in the army during World War II (and how many planes went down when they were not in combat), and survival in a brutal Japanese POW camp. Heavy on narrative and light on dialogue, the book drags for some readers (especially during the descriptions of the airplanes and combat flights), but I found the book to be completely gripping. 
 When Zamperini returns to the U.S., he suffers from alcoholism and post-traumatic stress disorder, which in those days was not talked about much less treated. 
 Of course, the most fascinating thing about the book is knowing that it's a true story and Louis Zamperini survived what seemed humanly impossible to endure...first while being lost at sea without food or water, somehow missing the circling and lunging sharks, and then while enduring brutal, horrific treatment at the hands of the Japanese guards, who believed it was shameful to be a POW and so took out their scorn in violent, inhumane ways. 
 After living in Japan and being welcomed by the Japanese people, it's hard to read about the brutality during the war. But Zamperini was able to forgive his Japanese captors and eventually returned to Japan, once to see his guards and extend an olive branch, and again to carry the torch at the Nagano Olympics. 
 Zamperini is in fact still alive and kicking, at age 95. Go to my blog post (at the top of this review) to see photos and a video."

review_text: b"This is a simply amazing story of a man's journey, almost literally to hell and back. The gut-wrenching recounting of the unrelentingly barbaric treatment of Louie and other POWs at Japanese prisons is hard to read at times. However, it makes Louie's recovery all the more astounding. For anyone who hasn't read much about WW II, this is a must read. It helps to explain why servicemen like Louie were such heroes and what they sacrificed for our country and the world."

review_text: b'This week I finally picked up my copy of the book, "Unbroken," a gift for Christmas last year from my mother and I decided to dive in. My one response as I peddled my way through this book was, "Wow. Absolutely incredible." The book was hard for me to put down. But what an amazing story it is---a story demonstrating the amazing determination drive of humanity, of the staggering depravity at the core of humanity, the gripping power of resentment and of alcohol, and the rudimentary effects of horrendous suffering in war. But the power of this story, though only given a small part of the book, centers on the power of the Lord Jesus Christ who delivered Louis from his anger, bitterness, hatred, desire for vengeance, and bondage to alcohol. If I were a history teacher this book would be required reading.'

review_text: b'This is the first detailed account I have read about how POWs were treated in Japan during WWII. I never realized the extent of the brutality our soldiers - and soldiers from other countries - endured at the hands of their captors. This book has given me a profound respect and admiration for these men and women. Unbroken is an amazing story of suffering and survival - both physical and emotional. Though it focuses on the individual story of Louie Zamperini, this book is a window into the experiences of many others who sacrificed for our country. I am so glad I read this book.'

review_text:
b"I just read Unbroken, and the first word that comes to mind is astonishing. I'll be the first to embarrassingly admit that I didn't pay much attention in history class when I was younger. Nor did I care much about it. But as I read, all I kept thinking was, EVERYONE needs to read this. The entire book is set around WW2, focusing specifically on the battle with Japan. 
 The story starts off with the boyish childhood of Louis Zamperini: who his family is, where they are from, and where he grows up: Torrance, CA. It goes on to reveal how he turns his unruly life around when he becomes focused on running and his goal to enter the Olympics (which he does). At first when I began reading about his early years, I found myself wanting to skip ahead to the part where he enters the war, but I kept reading. And I'm glad I did. The entire beginning is a perfect prelude to the years beyond his Olympic dreams. 
 The story also branches off into other POWs' lives, allowing insight into multiple people, and the way it was written isn't confusing; in my edition, there are photos to help put faces to the names mentioned. 
 I still can't believe how someone, how any of the Pacific POWs, could have survived what happened in the Japanese camps. Nor did I know how many men died in flight training, without ever actually going into war. Once captured, how does someone survive the physical brutality and dehumanization that these men went through? It's mind-blowing and the last hundred pages are just as hard to swallow. 
 It also details Louis' life and others after the war: where they end up, who they marry, their kids, how long they live, and how the prisoners' traumatic experiences affected the rest of their lives. 
 Unbroken opened my eyes and my mind to the world's history, and I learned a lot. For me, a person that normally reads young adult science fiction books, this non-fiction book is a must read. 5 stars."

review_text: b"Fascinating and also difficult to read at times. Very intense. I was so emotionally involved that I had to skip ahead and find out what happened to Phil, and I cried when I did. What went on in the camps was horrifying and hard to read about, but it's important to do so. At the same time, it's important to embrace the spirit of forgiveness while still acknowledging how awful it really was. My grandmother tried to explain to me her fear and disgust in regards to the Japanese after WWII, and I can understand it better after reading this book (and others such as Iris Chang's Rape of Nanking). However, it's also important to try and understand that this behavior grew in part out of the culture itself: highly militaristic, with no respect for retreat or defeat or weakness. Having read the memoir of a kamikaze pilot it's obvious that the brutality displayed in the camps was also present even in the regular training of Japanese soldiers; as Hillenbrand suggests, some of the violence against POWs stemmed from the desire for low-ranking soldiers to lord it over the lower man on the totem pole. That said, I'm certainly not trying to excuse it or play it down. Many of the guards were pure sadists and psychopaths, sometimes chosen specifically for those qualities. Hillenbrand makes an effort to show that just like with anything else, there was a range of behavior, with moments of goodheartedness battling the brutality. The most important thing we can do is to look at the picture as a whole and try to understand all sides of it, in an effort to prevent this from happening again."

review_text:
b"I enjoyed this book and am giving it 5 stars for the incredible research the author put into this book. 
 I read it mainly during my lunch break at work. Not the easiest lunchtime reading, but it was still very interesting. 
 The beginning parts about the Olympics were good, also the raft adventure. It was a little hard to read so much about being captured by the Japanese but I did it. 
 I would have liked it if there had been more time spent in the book about Louie's later years but that would have made this book even longer than it was. However, I do love it when authors wrap things up neatly in their books and this did the trick."

review_text: b"Apparently, I am the last person on the face of the earth to read this book. In my defense, I've owned it for a while; I just forgot about it. Anyway: wow. What an amazing story. The story of the WWII experiences of Louie Zamperini is simply unbelievable. That one human has gone through such a journey seems unreal. A troublemaker as a kid, he went on to Olympic fame. From there, he ended up in the Pacific Front. Crashing in the pacific, adrift in the Pacific for over forty days, living off captured raw fish, rain water, all the while fending off hungry sharks: and this is just the beginning? I kept thinking: this can't possibly get worse. And then it got worse. Way worse. He ended up floating to the Japanese occupies Marshall Islands. And from there. . . \n Zamperini's story was one of the most powerful I've ever read. I would have preferred a 3.5 star review,coming not from the content, but from the delivery. Hillenbrand is not a strong story teller and I that really hurt the overall quality of the book. She was highly researched and informed. But her book came off as an extended newspaper article; full of details but lacking on humanness. This could have - should have - been much richer, the characters could have been much deeper. Now, perhaps, this isn't a fair criticism; Zamperini's story is so rich, so heavy, so unbelievable that maybe it is beyond the scope of any biographer to adequately convey. Nevertheless, I am glad I finally picked this book up, dusted it off. As of this writing, Zamperini, at 97, is still alive. That he survived at all and overcame the dark demons implanted in him by the atrocities he faced and that it is all true (!) is an amazing message."

review_text: b'Great story--a five star story.....The writing is lacking in the later part of the book.'
description:
In her long-awaited new book, Laura Hillenbrand writes with the same rich and vivid narrative voice she displayed in . Telling an unforgettable story of a man's journey into extremity, Unbroken is a testament to the resilience of the human mind, body, and spirit.On a May afternoon in 1943, an Army Air Forces bomber crashed into the Pacific Ocean and disappeared, leaving only a spray of debris and a slick of oil, gasoline, and blood. Then, on the ocean surface, a face appeared. It was that of a young lieutenant, the plane's bombardier, who was struggling to a life raft and pulling himself aboard. So began one of the most extraordinary odysseys of the Second World War.The lieutenant's name was Louis Zamperini. In boyhood, he'd been a cunning and incorrigible delinquent, breaking into houses, brawling, and fleeing his home to ride the rails. As a teenager, he had channeled his defiance into running, discovering a prodigious talent that had carried him to the Berlin Olympics and within sight of the four-minute mile. But when war had come, the athlete had become an airman, embarking on a journey that led to his doomed flight, a tiny raft, and a drift into the unknown.
Ahead of Zamperini lay thousands of miles of open ocean, leaping sharks, a foundering raft, thirst and starvation, enemy aircraft, and, beyond, a trial even greater. Driven to the limits of endurance, Zamperini would answer desperation with ingenuity; suffering with hope, resolve, and humor; brutality with rebellion. His fate, whether triumph or tragedy, would be suspended on the fraying wire of his will.
title: Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience, and Redemption

review_text: b"I thought I was the unluckiest person in the world... Louie Zamperini would give even me a run for my money. However, to say he's unlucky doesn't exactly cover it. Sure, his plane crashed and he spent 30+ days adrift at sea with the constant threat of sharks, hunger and dehydration. Sure, he finally found land, but unfortunately that land happened to be on enemy territory (Japan). Sure, he was imprisoned in a POW camp, his life threatened daily by torture, abuse, disease and a really mean guard. Eventually, the guard that relentlessly hassled him was transferred to another POW camp, only for Louie to find he would be transferred as well. Even one of those things, in its own right is bad, all of them happening one after the other is considerably worse... but he survived. Many Americans, Chinese, Germans, British didn't... he did, and he lived a long life, filled with family, after the war. This book is truly eye-opening, both to what happened to soldiers during the war and to how you should appreciate what you have, even if sometimes it doesn't feel that great."

review_text: b'I was glad to be reading this on Veteran\'s Day. My grandfather made the D-day invasion on Utah Beach in France but I was not as familiar with the dynamics going on in the Pacific. I learned a lot but especially that I do not like war. It has such far reaching effects. \n I really liked Laura Hillenbrand\'s last statement in the acknowledgements, "I come away from this book with the deepest appreciation for what these men endured, and what they sacrificed, for the good of humanity. It is to them that this book is dedicated."'

review_text: b"My word, what a book. I have yet to read a biography that has moved me so emotionally as Unbroken has. I've seen countless films, heard numerous songs, and read dozens of books dealing with the horrors the Allied forces faced during WWII. And it never ceases to amaze, disgust, frighten, or humble me. \n Louis Zamperini was an astonishing man, whose resiliency resonates throughout Laura Hillenbrand's exquisitely written book. To have experienced what he went through, and then to have the courage and faith to forgive and let go of his hate, is something I found myself wondering if I would ever have the strength to do. I'm in awe of this man, and of all the men captured and held prisoner in the Pacific Theatre of WWII. \n On a side note, I listened to the audio version of this book, read by Edward Herrmann and the narration is absolutely top notch."

review_text:
b"I am on my second reading of Trevor Noah's Born a Crime short memoir for two reasons: first, it's a very quick, enjoyable read with moments of humor, terror and disgust in it; second, because I want to understand how a person can come across so genuine but have moments that make you doubt their soul at a fundamental level. 
 Born a Crime is Noah's story of birth and survival under South African apartheid rule, the chaos after that rule fell and how his light skin (but not too light), dark skin (but not too dark), luck and nerve served and failed him. Each chapter, you read about how he engages in misfortune and adventure only to see one of his friends or family members be claimed by the oppressive governmental forces or the specter those forces cast, and just when you think it's going to be Noah himself, the finger of fate touches someone close to him. 
 The entire book is a loving tribute to his mother, who if even half the things were true, sounds like a model for all mothers and an outspoken work for reforming how we approach domestic abuse. He gives an unflinching eye on how far can you support someone who's willing to live in a bad relationship. 
 There's also enough visceral details on what poor and starving people use for food to last a reader a very long while. 
 What's definitely noticeable are the tales left behind in the margins: what happened to Teddy who went to jail for eating chocolates, how Trevor helped raise his two brothers after a harrowing event, and the challenges of becoming a comedian in South Africa and eventually the big question: how did he get out of South Africa? which is a recurring theme but unsatisfactorily never answered. The sad effect of these omissions is that it makes the book seem narcissistic at times which he readily cops to in the book, so that may be the truth. 
 Overall, while I feel enriched for his story and I'm happy he's made it out of that place, I like him a little less as a person."
description:
The compelling, inspiring, and comically sublime story of one man's coming-of-age, set during the twilight of apartheid and the tumultuous days of freedom that followed.
Trevor Noah's unlikely path from apartheid South Africa to the desk of The Daily Show began with a criminal act: his birth. Trevor was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother at a time when such a union was punishable by five years in prison. Living proof of his parents' indiscretion, Trevor was kept mostly indoors for the earliest years of his life, bound by the extreme and often absurd measures his mother took to hide him from a government that could, at any moment, steal him away. Finally liberated by the end of South Africa's tyrannical white rule, Trevor and his mother set forth on a grand adventure, living openly and freely and embracing the opportunities won by a centuries-long struggle.
Born a Crimeis the story of a mischievous young boy who grows into a restless young man as he struggles to find himself in a world where he was never supposed to exist. It is also the story of that young man's relationship with his fearless, rebellious, and fervently religious mother: his teammate, a woman determined to save her son from the cycle of poverty, violence, and abuse that would ultimately threaten her own life.
The eighteen personal essays collected here are by turns hilarious, dramatic, and deeply affecting. Whether subsisting on caterpillars for dinner during hard times, being thrown from a moving car during an attempted kidnapping, or just trying to survive the life-and-death pitfalls of dating in high school, Trevor illuminates his curious world with an incisive wit and unflinching honesty. His stories weave together to form a moving and searingly funny portrait of a boy making his way through a damaged world in a dangerous time, armed only with a keen sense of humor and a mother's unconventional, unconditional love.
title: Born a Crime: Stories From a South African Childhood

review_text: b'This is a phenomenal memoir by Trevor Noah the late night comedian who took over for Jon Stewart. I had no idea that Noah was South African and that he grew up under the evils of apartheid. It was illegal for blacks and whites to have sex or relations and since he was a product of such a union, he was "Born a Crime. The work explores race, poverty, abuse, alcoholism, getting by with little, fierce maternal love, and the art of the hustle. I listened to the audiobook narrated by himself, which was a special treat. Loved It!!'

review_text: b"Best book I've read so far this year and probably one of the best memoirs I've read.Period. In his own way, Noah gets you to understand the post-apartheid era in South Africa. A country, that like a modern day Picasso is full of complex emotions and social paradoxes and one that only a master story-teller can hope to describe. Noah does that brilliantly, keeping you swinging from laughter to tears and back, one sentence at a time. Can't recommend it highly enough."

review_text: b'This was a fascinating read. Trevor Noah maintained his level of humor while remaining honest and reflective of his childhood in South Africa. It is such a unique story and I am grateful he takes the time to tell it. My only critique is I was expecting a part of the book to discuss his career and how he grew into comedy and came to America. But on further reflection, I realize that is not what the purpose of the book was; the purpose was to tell stories of his childhood as a colored child in South Africa. And it was excellent.'

review_text:
b'I enjoy Trevor Noah on TV and was interested to read his memoir--- because I don't know a lot about South Africa. I didn't expect much. 
 This is the story of his childhood/adolescence and growing up with his single mother-- a story of surviving life in South Africa and being treated as a second class citizen. We learn about his family and what he did in high school. This book does not go past the first couple of years out of high school--- nor does it touch on him becoming a comedian, but it is really well written and gives a good idea about life in South Africa for a "colored" child. 
 I hope he continues to write--- I would love how he went from a DJ in SA to a late night tv host in NYC.... 
 Read if you enjoy autobiographies or want to learn more about South Africa.'

review_text: b"Seemed like a natural follow-up to The Daily Show's oral history -- but Noah doesn't really address his stand-up career or his takeover from Jon Stewart; instead, he focuses on growing up in apartheid-era South Africa and how it shaped him as a person. Noah's mom sounds like an absolute badass lady, and after reading this book I can see why he mentions her so often. I've read plenty of history but this is the first memoir I can remember reading that explicitly addresses some of the complications of growing up under apartheid -- it's worth reading for the history lesson alone, but Noah's heart and unique perspective on life really come through in his writing. It reminded me why I had been so excited for him to take over The Daily Show in the first place."

review_text: b"Trevor Noah is an interesting person. His memoir is unusually structured. He tells and re-tells his story from slightly different points-of-view about four or five times over. I couldn't help but to think that he might have just put down his comedy routines on paper and really didn't edit it into a whole. He is very entertaining and seems very smart."

review_text:
b"I am not big on non-fiction. I am not big on audio books either. So for me to give this book five stars is pretty surprising. 
 As I said, I listened to this on audio book, which I recommend. Noah is narrating it and I always like when that's the case with autobiographies. He does a great job, and hearing him imitate accents and talking in different langagues gives life to the whole thing. 
 I think this autobiography was really skillfully crafted. The way he jumped back and forth in time, making associations, telling little side-anecdotes, but always driving the chapter home in the ens was impressive. I also really enjoyed the topic: I know very little about South Africa and Apartheid, so I was eager to learn. And so I did, thanks to the way this was told. 
 Noah found a great balance between political, personal, funny and emotional and I am glad that I took the chance on him."

review_text: b"This was so much more than a comedian memoir. A story of understanding South African apartheid, coming of age, making trouble, loving his mother, and suffering domestic violence. I listened to the audiobook narrated by Trevor, and I couldn't believe how he kept his composure. But it was a lovely reading, and hearing the Tonga and Zulu spoken was wonderful. The ending was shocking, heartful, and satisfying -- very intelligently arranged as mostly chronological, but slightly out of order for maximum plot development."

review_text:
b"Holy shit. If there is one book that you need to read this year, let it be this one. 
 Been trying to prolong the lifespan of this book by limiting myself to only a few pages a day. That's how good it was. 
 Though far from being lyrical or poetic, this was beautifully written in a raw and honest way. Hilarious and illuminating throughout. The last chapter where he talks about how his mother survived a shot to the face gave me chills. 
 This book cannot receive too much hype and I now have mad respect for Trevor Noah."

review_text: b"This book was truly terrific! Part of me wished I had listened to the audiobook which I believe Trevor Noah narrates, but the book was a super-quick, engaging read that brings to life a post-apartheid world. Growing up during the time of apartheid, I had some vague awareness what it was but Noah does a masterful job describing just how oppressive the regime was while still introducing humor, perspective and admiration for what he and his family endured. His mother was a major influence in his life and you cannot help but to respect and empathize with this incredibly strong and resilient woman whose love for her children was undeniable. I internalized much about relationships, race, language and poverty and look forward to watching more Daily Show after this which will be all the more poignant because of the additional context I have now about Trevor Noah's life."

review_text: b"I very much enjoyed this book - I listened to the (self-narrated) audiobook which was very enjoyable, sometimes disturbing, often amusing. I would recommend this book to anyone who wants to understand more about life in apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa. \n I only rated it three stars because I'm not comfortable with some of the timeline and authenticity of this book. I was astonished to learn, after reading, that Trevor Noah's mother converted to Judaism when he was a child. He had a Bar Mitzvah that was ill-attended. Was he unable to reconcile this part of his mother's life with the rest of his story? I want to know whether she was, indeed, still calling on the name of Jesus by the time he was 19 (at the end of the book). \n South African reviewers question whether he was really hidden away until the age of six; when anti-mixing laws were overturned when he was two years old. I can accept his version of these facts, because this was the impression he had when he was a child. I still recommend this book, with the understanding that his reality may not have been the average reality of a mixed-race child in South Africa during that time period."

review_text: b"Audible. Read by the author. \n Full disclosure: I really like was Noah's been doing with The Daily Show. review_text: b"You see Trevor Noah and you see a man who's funny, successful, suave and brilliant. Until you read this memoir, you don't know much about the life he's lived--one filled with issues and conflicts of class, race, politics, language, power and gender. This is a must read book, not just because it's funny but because it'll teach you about empathy, tolerance, and negotiating his particular life, schools, childhood and youth in South Africa."

review_text: b"Enjoyed this a lot. Listened to this - the only way to do it, with Trevor Noah reading in the multiple languages he speaks. The timeline jumps around a lot which was a bit confusing and his sometimes flippant tone was in stark contrast to the content which was funny at times and unnerving at others."

review_text: b'"But the real world doesn\'t go away. Racism exists. People are getting hurt. And just because it\'s not happening to you, doesn\'t mean it\'s not happening. And at some point you have to choose; black or white, pick a side. You can try to hide from it. You can say, oh I don\'t take sides, but at some point, life will force you to pick a side." \n -- Trevor Noah, Born a Crime \n Just finished listening to Trevor Noah\'s book "born a crime" which is narrated by Trevor Noah and well, it is a damn good book. Trevor has a masterful way of using humor to make strong and powerful statements about the way he and others view race and identity. Through his humor and careful selection of poignant moments in his life, Trevor is able to give us insight into the world of a boy trying to find his way in a world where he was born a crime. This is the first audiobook I have listened completely and while I find his stories relatable and clever; the intimacy of hearing these words spoken from his own voice was what made this experience more powerful.This book made me laugh, made me think and also made me cry. Everyone should give it a chance.'

review_text: b"Terrific! So glad I listened to this. Who better to tell the funny and heartbreaking stories of Trevor Noah's life than Trevor Noah? description:
The compelling, inspiring, and comically sublime story of one man's coming-of-age, set during the twilight of apartheid and the tumultuous days of freedom that followed.
Trevor Noah's unlikely path from apartheid South Africa to the desk of The Daily Show began with a criminal act: his birth. Trevor was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother at a time when such a union was punishable by five years in prison. Living proof of his parents' indiscretion, Trevor was kept mostly indoors for the earliest years of his life, bound by the extreme and often absurd measures his mother took to hide him from a government that could, at any moment, steal him away. Finally liberated by the end of South Africa's tyrannical white rule, Trevor and his mother set forth on a grand adventure, living openly and freely and embracing the opportunities won by a centuries-long struggle.
Born a Crimeis the story of a mischievous young boy who grows into a restless young man as he struggles to find himself in a world where he was never supposed to exist. It is also the story of that young man's relationship with his fearless, rebellious, and fervently religious mother: his teammate, a woman determined to save her son from the cycle of poverty, violence, and abuse that would ultimately threaten her own life.
The eighteen personal essays collected here are by turns hilarious, dramatic, and deeply affecting. Whether subsisting on caterpillars for dinner during hard times, being thrown from a moving car during an attempted kidnapping, or just trying to survive the life-and-death pitfalls of dating in high school, Trevor illuminates his curious world with an incisive wit and unflinching honesty. His stories weave together to form a moving and searingly funny portrait of a boy making his way through a damaged world in a dangerous time, armed only with a keen sense of humor and a mother's unconventional, unconditional love.
title: Born a Crime: Stories From a South African Childhood

review_text: b"I had the wrong expectations going in, expecting more humour from the well-known comedian. The value of the book surpasses that though, by far. It is an earnest revelation of the day-to-day realities of Trevor Noah's childhood, which is clearly something that will be familiar to many South African readers. It was helpful for me as a pale male to get that insight of a life I didn't live. \n There is great great sadness in this book, and the praised love of the author's mother is a shining light in the midst of it. \n It's worth the read."

review_text: b"I'm not any great fan of Ernest Hemingway, which might be part of the reason I wasn't crazy about this book. McLain obviously knows how to write, but here she seems to be mimicking Hemingway's pared down style, making her narrator, Hadley, read as passive and, frankly, impotent. Hadley narrates what should be intensely emotional anecdotes--her father's suicide, the birth and life of her child, her husband's betrayals, and the breakup of her marriage--with dispassionate summary. It put up a wall between me and the character and, as a result, I skimmed through like I was reading newspaper headlines. I also got a bit tired of reading one paragraph describing how poor she and Hemingway were and how much they had to scrimp and sacrifice, and then a following paragraph describing her nanny and the extended vacations they took all over Europe. Yep. Poor people have nannies. \n There were some interesting bits, like hearing about the characters who inhabited France and the Hemingways' lives, and how Hemingway incorporated his friends into his fiction. But so much of it felt like pure conjecture (I'm thinking specifically of the italicized passages [huge passages of italics, ugh] of third-person p.o.v. from Papa Hem himself about encounters with vixens trying to seduce him away from his poor homely wife, and his early suicidal fascinations). I guess I'm not a fan of historical fiction for a reason--I'd much rather just read a solid history or biography instead of something with such pretense."
description:
A deeply evocative story of ambition and betrayal, The Paris Wife captures a remarkable period of time and a love affair between two unforgettable people: Ernest Hemingway and his wife Hadley.
Chicago, 1920: Hadley Richardson is a quiet twenty-eight-year-old who has all but given up on love and happiness--until she meets Ernest Hemingway and her life changes forever. Following a whirlwind courtship and wedding, the pair set sail for Paris, where they become the golden couple in a lively and volatile group--the fabled "Lost Generation"--that includes Gertrude Stein, Ezra Pound, and F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald.
Though deeply in love, the Hemingways are ill prepared for the hard-drinking and fast-living life of Jazz Age Paris, which hardly values traditional notions of family and monogamy. Surrounded by beautiful women and competing egos, Ernest struggles to find the voice that will earn him a place in history, pouring all the richness and intensity of his life with Hadley and their circle of friends into the novel that will become The Sun Also Rises. Hadley, meanwhile, strives to hold on to her sense of self as the demands of life with Ernest grow costly and her roles as wife, friend, and muse become more challenging. Despite their extraordinary bond, they eventually find themselves facing the ultimate crisis of their marriage--a deception that will lead to the unraveling of everything they've fought so hard for.
A heartbreaking portrayal of love and torn loyalty, The Paris Wife is all the more poignant because we know that, in the end, Hemingway wrote that he would rather have died than fallen in love with anyone but Hadley.
title: The Paris Wife

review_text: b"I enjoyed the writing style as well as the in depth look at Paris during this time. However, I did not have a lot of sympathy for the characters and the structure of the book bothered me. I wish there was more to it, more story more depth. But you knew how this story ended, she tells you in the beginning if you didn't know the history. So I thought there would be some new discovery, something interesting to explore but there wasn't. It's just the sad story of a failed marriage."
